Seek for professional and responsive Technical Support on the customer perspective

AhnLab's Technical Assistance Center provides various services such as guidelines and solutions to various inquiries and problems that customers may have while using our products. Please check the following prior to requesting consulting service or technical support to ensure fast and accurate troubleshooting procedures.

  • Check Online Help or Administrator's Guide. Online Help and Administrator's Guide offer extensive and useful information about AhnLab products and services, which might help you solve your problem before you contact customer service.
  • Please note that your program is a licensed and registered version. If you have not registered the product properly, you may not be provided with customer support for licensed product users only.
  • Please be sure that your program and engine have been updated to the latest versions. Many program errors are solved by updating the program and engine to their latest versions. If the problem still remains unsolved, please contact our Technical Assistance Center.

Definition

RBH (Regional Business Hours)

Regional Business Hours (RBH) are the hours between 7:00 AM EST and 7:00 PM EST for the United States, 9:00 AM GMT and 5:30 PM GMT for the EMEA region (or 9:00 UTC and 17:30 UTC) and 9:00 AM KST and 06:00 PM KST for the APAC region, Monday through Friday excluding holidays.

RWH (Regional Weekend Hours)

Regional Weekend Hours (RWH) are the hours between 8:00 AM EST and 8:00 PM EST for the United States, 10:00 AM GMT and 5:00 PM GMT for the EMEA region (or 10:00 UTC and 17:00 UTC) and 10:00 AM KST and 5:00 PM KST for the APAC region, Saturday and Sunday.

ATAC (AhnLab Technical Assistance Center)

ATAC (AhnLab Technical Assistance Center) is web-based global portal system for technical support which is operated by AhnLab. ATAC provides partners who have access authority with Case-Open(Support Inquiries) of existing customers and technical documentation.

What is AhnReport?

In order to respond to the problems on your computer promptly and accurately,
AhnReport collects your system information and sends them to AhnLab security experts for analysis.

Download AhnReport

Information collected
by AhnReport

  • PC System Information & Operating System(OS)
  • Files and program information that can influence or is related to AhnLab Products
    • Collected information will not be used for other purposes.
    • Process of collecting your system information may take more than 5 minutes

How to
use AhnReport

  1. 1. Click Download AhnReport button and save the file in a temporary folder.
  2. 2. Run the saved ‘AhnReport.exe’ file.
  3. 3. To report suspicious activities, click ‘Error Report’ or ‘Malicious Code Report’ button on the top of the program.
  4. 4. Enter ‘Name’ and “Description”.
  5. 5. If file attachment is needed, use ‘Suspicious Files’ or ‘Other Files’ menu.
  6. 6. Click ‘Send’ to finalize Error Report.
  7. 7. To finalize ‘Malicious Code Report’, Click ‘Save’ and save your AhnReport file. Then submit it HERE.
  • For Technical support on our solutions, please refer to our Product FAQ.
  • For questions regarding open sources used in AhnLab products, contact us at opensource@ahnlab.com or visit http://opensource.ahnlab.com
  • To require further support, please contact us at global.support@ahnlab.com.
What is the difference between Clean Wise and Clean Wide?

Clean Wise (quick scan) scans currently running programs and memory status, and performs minimum possible optimization. Short-click to start Clean Wise.

Clean Wide (full scan) scans your entire system, including all drives (except network drive) and programs, so it takes longer, but it is more thorough. Long-click to start Clean Wide.
What do the different colored lights on V3 Click mean?

Green light: All the security features are working properly and your computer is safe.

Blue flashing light: V3 Click is performing a task. (Clean Wise or Clean Wide is running, update is running or USB flash drive is being scanned.)

Red flashing light: V3 Click detected a security threat, and automatically removed/repaired it. If you click V3 Click, you will see the details, and the icon will change back to green.

Orange light: V3 Click is not properly installed, or is not working properly, so you computer is at risk. You can solve this issue by reinstalling it.

If the problem persists, please contact our Customer Center .
I can’t remember my password after encrypting a file. Can you help me?
Unfortunately we cannot help you with retrieving your password.
Anti-Theft allows you to remotely locate, lock and wipe your phone if it’s lost or stolen. With a remote command and password you can remotely control your device by sending messages.
The message "service.exe terminated unexpectedly with Status Code 128." is displayed and the system reboots automatically after 60 seconds.

This symptom is associated with Win32/Zotob.worm that attempts to infect your system, exploiting Windows vulnerability (MS05-039). 

When Win32/Zotob.worm infects your system, it creates files in the Windows system folder and opens TCP # 33333 port, and then attempts to connect the specific IRC server using random ports. Once the connection is established successfully, Win32/Zotob.worm activates many malicious functions by the command from the offer. 
This is an attack that exploits OS vulnerability. You should install the following patches to avoid this attack. 
[How to install the patch] 
1) Download and install the security patches, Plug-and-Play Vulnerability (MS05-039) Exploit for your version of Windows from the URL below. [Required] 
 - Go to Microsoft Security Bulletin MS05-039 vulnerability page  
2) Reboot the system. 
3) Install all the security patches that MS recommends via the following steps; [Run Internet Explorer]-[Tools]-[Windows Update]-[Check for Updates and Install]-[Install Now]. [Required] 
However, if you cannot use the method described above due to the system rebooting every 60 seconds, please run a removal tool for the security hole as the following steps. 
1. Download and execute V3 FirstBlock for pnp vulnerability.exe from the page below.
 - Go to the RemovalTools page for PnP Vulnerability (MS05-039)
2. When executed, it blocks the attacking packets. 
   You can check the log by clicking ‘Network’ tab in the main window. 
3. Proceed as instructed in [How to install the patch] above, when V3 FirstBlock for pnp vulnerability is running. 
V3 FirstBlock for PnP Vulnerability detects and blocks the attacking packets only. It does not detect or repair malicious codes exploiting the vulnerability. You need to scan against viruses after updating Windows.
For your reference, this vulnerability does not affect Windows 9x (95, 98, 98SE, Me) systems. It threatens mainly Windows 2000 systems and may affect unpatched Windows XP systems. 
 - Go to Win32/Zotob.worm.31744 information
 - Go to Win32/Zotob.worm.15386 information 
 - Go to Win32/Zotob.worm.22528 information
The system reboots in safe mode and the mouse pointer disappears.

This symptom can be caused by Win-Trojan/SystEntry.32768 variant. This happens when Windows does not operate properly because SYSTEM.INI is corrupted in Windows folder (typically C:\Windows), due to the Win-Trojan/SystEntry.32768.B bug. If you have abnormal Windows status, please click here to restore the system according to the specified method. For your reference, this problem is caused when System.ini that manages device drivers in Windows 9x (Windows 95, 98, Me) is overwritten by the contents written by the Trojan horse due to its bug. (This does not happen in Windows 2000 series because Windows 2000 does not refer to System.ini.) You can detect, repair or remove Win-Trojan/SystEntry.32768.B with the latest V3 engine.

[Notice] Another OpenSSL Security Issue Response FAQ

Summary

 

1. What are the new OpenSSL vulnerability and its impact?


Another vulnerabilities in OpenSSL have been revealed. These vulnerabilities can be exploited to decrypt and modify SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) and TLS (Transport Layer Security) traffic between clients and servers that use OpenSSL, if the version of the library on the server is 1.0.1 or newer. Also, these vulnerabilities can allow a remote attacker to cause a denial of service or run arbitrary code.

 

 

OpenSSL Vulnerability [05 Jun 2014]

 

■ SSL/TLS MITM vulnerability (CVE-2014-0224)
The attacker can decrypt and modify traffic from the attacked client and server.

 

■ DTLS recursion flaw (CVE-2014-0221)
By sending an invalid DTLS handshake to an OpenSSL DTLS client the code can be made to recur eventually crashing in a DoS attack.

 

■ DTLS invalid fragment vulnerability (CVE-2014-0195)
By sending invalid DTLS fragments to an OpenSSL DTLS client or server can run arbitrary code on a vulnerable client or server.

 

■ SSL_MODE_RELEASE_BUFFERS NULL pointer dereference (CVE-2014-0198)
The attacker can launch a denial of service via a NULL pointer dereference.

 

■ SSL_MODE_RELEASE_BUFFERS session injection or denial of service (CVE-2010-5298)
The attacker can inject data across sessions or cause a denial of service.

 

■ Anonymous ECDH denial of service (CVE-2014-3470)
OpenSSL TLS clients enabling anonymous ECDH ciphersuites are subject to a denial of service attack. 

 

 

2. What are the affected AhnLab products?

 

 

Only some versions of these AhnLab products are affected:

 

AhnLab TrusGuard v2.1.0, v2.1.2, v2.1.3
AhnLab TrusGuard Manager (ATM) v1.5.6.8, v1.5.7.5, v1.5.8.10
AhnLab TrusGuard LogServer (ATL) v2.1.2.3
AhnLab Policy Center Appliance (APC) v4.5.12, v4.5.13, v4.5.14, v4.5.15 (APC 4.0 Windows not affected.)
AhnLab DPS v1.0.6, v1.0.7

AhnLab MDS v2.1.3

AhnLab TrusLine v2.0.2.2
AhnLab EPS v1.0.2.14

 


Security Advisory for AhnLab Product Users

 

3. I am using an affected product. When will the patch be available?


AhnLab is currently developing updates that address the vulnerability. Details will be provided when the patches are released.
* AhnLab is developing updates that are consistent with various environments and testing various areas to verify its stability. It usually takes several months to verify the stability of a simple change in function. AhnLab is releasing updates as fast as possible to assuage any concerns you may have about this security issue and to provide stable services.


** The updated patches AhnLab will provide are to prevent any future exploits of OpenSSL vulnerabilities.

 

 

 

4. What measures should I take before the updated patches are available?


Control access to your system by registering administrative IPs to allow and apply patches as soon as they are available.

 

 

5. How do I certify the updated patches?


Software vulnerabilities are certified by the National Intelligence Service’s CC certification. The National Intelligence Service advises to verify and upgrade encryption regularly to remediate vulnerabilities, and AhnLab is complying with the recommendation.
 

 

6. If I have inquiries about the updated patches, whom do I contact?
 

Please refer to the following contact information.

 

[North America_ AhnLab US]
- Email : info@ahnlab.com

 

[Japan_ AhnLab Japan]

 

- Email : webmaster@ahnlab.co.jp

 

 

[China_AhnLab China]
- Email : v3site@ahn.com.cn

 

[Other regions_AhnLab HQ Korea]
- Tel : +82-31-722-7998+82-31-722-7998
- Email : global_sa@ahnlab.com
[August 2005] Vulnerability found in Microsoft Plug and Play

Security risk found in July

Summer is turning to Fall, the leaves are beginning to collect on the ground and, although we have to say goodbye to the summer sun for the time being, we have a hot new issue to which we must turn our attention. Earlier this month Microsoft announced the discovery of a new MS05-039 Plug and Play (PnP) service vulnerability. In reaction to this announcement, ASEC ( AhnLab Security E-response Center ) began preparing for the inevitable appearance of worms and viruses expected to take advantage of this newfound weakness. As we anticipated, our vigilance paid off and allowed for the early discovery of new worms and malicious code circulating on the Net. Early detection of this kind of threat is critical to decrease the creation time of malicious code and to prevent a truly widespread outbreak.
System Risk Vulnerability Malicious
Code (YES/NO)
MID Vulnerability of Remote code execution exist in Msdds.dll library YES
MID Microsoft Windows RDP(Remote Desktop Protocol) Denial of Service Attack (MS05-041) YES
HIGH Internet Explorer COM Objects related vulnerability (MS05-038) YES
HIGH Microsoft PnP(Plug and Play) Buffer overflow Vulnerability (MS05-039) YES
[1] Major vulnerability found in August
Malicious code exposure and expected Worm appearance

The risk to computer users by malicious code has been on the rise lately as vulnerabilities and security breaches are uncovered within their systems. In particular, Microsoft (MS) products have been a major target for these forms of attack. In an attempt to counter this onslaught, MS releases security vulnerability patches on the second Tuesday of every month. In their most recent release, Microsoft announced 6 patches. From these patches, the PnP service was noted to have the weakness of remote execution which allows it to be used by malicious code as a spring board into a user's system. These types of attacks are especially insidious because of the multitude of users who can be affected and the ease with which vulnerabilities can go unnoticed.
Displayed below is a time table which lists the events that took place from the announcement of MS05-039 to the appearance of the first instance of malicious code.

2005/08/09 MS05-039 MS announce Security vulnerability warning
2005/08/11 MS05-039 first and second attacking code found ( Infrequent attacking code)
2005/08/12 MS05-039 third attacking code found (Code that used on Malicious code)
2005/08/14 Zotob.A worm discovered (Afternoon of 14th)
2005/08/14 Zotob.B
2005/08/15 Zotob.C - Mass Mailer feature included

Within three days of the announcement, the malicious code used within the worm had been exposed. Two days after this exposure, the (Zotob) worm was discovered. It can typically be expected that as time proceeds and the awareness of vulnerabilities is increased, the interval between release and discovery of malicious code decreases, thereby reducing the potential damage caused by these and other harmful internet threats. The development of the malicious code used in this worm was claimed by the creator of the Blaster Worm. Even though the offending code targeted only Windows 2000, and it had an inaccurate offset position on Korean Windows systems, system administrators and end-users need to be especially aware of vulnerabilities that can contribute to the widespread destruction caused by worms such as these.

AhnLab ASEC
Written by Jung Kwang Jin, Sr. Researcher
[ASEC_Advisory] AhnLab V3 Specific Compressed File Handling Vulnerability

f¸逽

Severity Rate: High

Overview
A buffer overflow vulnerability was discovered which could let attackers execute arbitrary privileged commands. This issue takes place when an application scans maliciously manipulated compressed file types for viruses.

Type of Attack
An attacker can exploit the flaw by sending a maliciously crafted compressed file (ALZ/UUE/XXE) which can be used to execute arbitrary commands.

Affected Software
 - AhnLab V3Pro 2004(AhnLab V3 VirusBlock 2005 international)
 - AhnLab V3Net for Windows Server 6.0
 - AhnLab MyV3

Impact
There exists a buffer overflow vulnerability during scanning of maliciously crafted compressed files. The successful exploitation of this flaw could potentially allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands or create malicious files on the targeted system.

Description
The buffer overflow vulnerability is exposed when scanning specific compressed files that were manipulated by malicious users. An exploit of this vulnerability can lead to arbitrary code execution attacks. This flaw affects ALZ, UUE, XXE compressed file formats. This issue is due to a failure of the application to properly check the byte size of the file name before copying it into buffers. Compressed file formats other than the three mentioned above are not affected by this threat. By default, the manual scan of V3Pro 2004 does not scan compressed files for viruses. Therefore, it will be necessary for the compressed file scan option to be enabled in order for this vulnerability to be exploited.

Solution
AhnLab has released a scan engine that fixes this vulnerability. We recommend that you run the Smart Update Utility to update to the latest scan engine. The Smart Update Utility helps keep AhnLab products up to date. To manually invoke the Smart Update Utility, do one of the following:

 Click Start->All Programs->AhnLab->Smart Update Utility->Smart Update Utility.
 Click Update on the tool bar.

The following image will display when the application starts.
Click Start to begin updating and downloading files from our update server. It may take several minutes to complete depending on the connection speed.

 

Caution
In order for the latest engine to be updated, your computer must be connected to the Internet.

Below is a list of fixed versions.

 To see build information, click on Help and select Product Information.

Product Name Version
AhnLab V3Pro 2004 Later than 6.0.0.488
AhnLab V3Net for Windows Server 6.0 Later than 6.0.0.488
AhnLab MyV3 Not Vulnerable as of October 11, 2005

Acknowledgement
We especially thank Chew Keong Tan of Secunia(http://www.secunia.com) for reporting this issue and helping us to find a solution.

ASEC Contact Information

Email: asec@ahnlab.com

Threat Analysis

ASEC (AhnLab Security Emergency Response Center)
ASEC (AhnLab Security Emergency Response Center) is a world-class emergency response organization comprised of malware researchers and security experts. ASEC monitors security threats around-the-clock, collects and analyzes malicious codes with its own threat identification rules. This team then promptly provides new malware signatures and responses. Its deep insight into today’s security environment and constant availability gives AhnLab the capability to quickly mitigate complex and evolving security issues.
AhnLab CERT
AhnLab’s CERT (Computer Emergency Response Team) monitors and responds to outbreaks and attacks 24/7. With its extensive experience and know-how, AhnLab’s CERT contributes to preventing security threats from spreading around the world.

Cloud-based Intelligence

ASD (AhnLab Smart Defense)
ASD (AhnLab Smart Defense) is a cloud-computing based security system of AhnLab and strategy. Samples collected from numerous sensors around the world are analyzed using a variety of analytic methods. Also, ASD implements the Hybrid Analysis System (HAS) to quickly identify unknown malware, and develops signatures in a fraction of the time.
ASD system provides a legitimate solution to the problems with today’s current security environment. This cloud-based system drastically improves response time, reduces the need for system resources, and ultimately provides security intelligence. Based on ASD strategy, AhnLab’s technologies and solutions seamlessly converge into a single platform to cope with evolving IT security challenges. The rapid, automated response of ASD system increases the likelihood of preventing unknown malware and zero-day attacks, and seamlessly updates all our products simultaneously. Learn more

Endpoint Security

AhnLab helps corporates of all sizes keep their systems - PCs, servers, mobile and other service systems – safe and reliable by protecting them against malware such as viruses, worms and spyware.

  • V3 Internet Security: Anti-malware solution for PCs Learn more
  • V3 Net for Windows Server: Anti-malware solution for servers Learn more
  • AhnLab Policy Center: Endpoint management solution Learn more
  • AhnLab EPS: Whitelist-based security solution for industrial/POS systems Learn more
  • AhnLab Online Security: Anti-fraud for endpoint Learn more
  • AhnLab HackShield for Online Games: Online game hacking prevention Learn more
  • AhnLab TS Engine Suite: Interlocking anti-virus/spyware engine Learn more
  • AhnLab V3 Mobile: Anti-virus program for mobile Learn more
  • AhnLab Mobile Smart Defense: Application verification system for Android Learn more

Network Security

Managing a security infrastructure to combat threats is increasingly challenging as networks grow in size and complexity. AhnLab provides solutions that give you network-wide visibility of your security platform and eliminate unnecessary management overhead.

  • AhnLab TrusGuard: UTM and firewall Learn more
  • AhnLab DPS: DDoS attack mitigation Learn more

Advanced Threat Defense

Today’s advanced targeted malware evades typical security defenses – but not AhnLab’s advanced threat protection solutions. AhnLab delivers fast, truly comprehensive host and network protection against known and unknown malware, zero-day exploits, and targeted attacks.

  • AhnLab MDS: Advanced threat protection through dynamic payload and network traffic analysis Learn more
  • AhnLab MDSE: Endpoint threat analysis and response through full inspection Learn more

Services

AhnLab provides exceptional security services with the dedicated, highly-trained professionals who are capable of responding to advanced and sophisticated security incidents.

  • Managed Security Services Learn more
  • IT Security Consulting Services Learn more
  • Forensic Services Learn more
Frost & Sullivan Recognizes AhnLab with the 2015 South Korea Technology Innovation Award in APT Solutions

Frost & Sullivan Recognizes AhnLab with the 2015 South Korea Technology Innovation Award in APT Solutions

  • Date2015-09-21
  • Hit3116

SEOUL, Sept 17, 2015 – Frost & Sullivan has recognized AhnLab Inc with the 2015 South Korea Technology Innovation Award in Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) solutions.


Mr. Charles Lim, Senior Industry Analyst, Networking, Information and Cyber Security, Asia Pacific at Frost & Sullivan said that AhnLab has differentiated itself from other security vendors in its drive for excellence in developing a holistic APT solution in South Korea.


“In its latest MDS – Malware Defense System lineup, AhnLab has developed several proprietary algorithms to analyze advanced malware and various attack vectors across the network, providing the right approach to mitigate threats and perform remediation as a total solution,” he added.


He said that AhnLab uses a hybrid technology of static analysis and dynamic analysis to detect malware with its automated analysis technology at the assembly-level. With this, it is capable of blocking and analyzing evasive malware or variants that infiltrate into the endpoint via various ways, such as encrypted traffic using SSL, a USB drive or though the trusted internal network.


He added that due to its product efficiencies, the industry views AhnLab as the top 2 vendors in South Korea, which also puts the company within the top 10 APT vendors in Asia Pacific.


“The MDS’ ease of use, clear visibility of attack vectors and accuracy of detection were well-received by key IT security professionals in the region,” Mr. Lim said.

 


 


AhnLab Vice President, Mr. Suk-kyoon Kang said the company is honored to be recognized with the 2015 South Korea Technology Innovation Award in APT Solutions by Frost & Sullivan, a reputable consulting firm.


“I would like to dedicate the award to all our employees for their hard work. It really motivates us to continue to provide all our clients with the best APT solutions,” he said.


The Frost & Sullivan South Korea Excellence awards, in its fourth year running now, have identified and honored best-in-class companies that have demonstrated excellence in their respective industries.

 

The recipients of the 2015 Frost & Sullivan South Korea Excellence Awards were identified based on an in-depth research conducted by Frost & Sullivan's analysts. The award categories offered each year are carefully reviewed and evaluated to reflect the current market landscape and include new emerging trends.

 

The short-listed companies were evaluated on a variety of actual market performance indicators which include revenue growth; market share and growth in market share; leadership in product innovation; marketing strategy and business development strategy.

 

 

About Frost & Sullivan
Frost & Sullivan, the Growth Partnership Company, works in collaboration with clients to leverage visionary innovation that addresses the global challenges and related growth opportunities that will make or break today's market participants. 

For more than 50 years, we have been developing growth strategies for the global 1000, emerging businesses, the public sector and the investment community. Is your organization prepared for the next profound wave of industry convergence, disruptive technologies, increasing competitive intensity, Mega Trends, breakthrough best practices, changing customer dynamics and emerging economies?   Contact Us: Start the discussion

 

About AhnLab, Inc.
AhnLab creates agile, integrated Internet security solutions for consumers and businesses, ranging in size from SMBs to enterprise organizations. Founded in 1995, AhnLab is a global leader in security research and product development that delivers comprehensive protection for networks, transactions, and essential services. By combining cloud analysis with endpoint and server resources, AhnLab generates best-of-breed breach detection and threat prevention that scales easily for large and high-speed networks. This multi-dimensional approach combines with exceptional service to create truly global protection against attacks that evade traditional security defenses. That’s why more than 25,000 organizations rely on AhnLab’s award-winning products and services to make the Internet safe and reliable for their business operations.
Learn more today by contacting your AhnLab partner or local AhnLab sales representative, visit www.ahnlab.com.

AhnLab V3 Received ‘2015 EIST’ Award By ICSA Labs

Seoul, March 7, 2016 — AhnLab, Inc., the global leader in cybersecurity, announced today that AhnLab V3, its anti-virus solution program, won the ICSA Labs’ 2016 Excellence in Information Security Testing Award.

 

ICSA Labs (hereafter “ICSA”), a global security product testing and certification organization, awards the EIST Award in recognition of vendors who have passed its certification test every month without fail for a 5-year period. The honor indicates that the award recipient has maintained and cultivated a consistently high technical prowess in security solutions. 

 

AhnLab’s trademark V3 anti-virus solution receives this distinguished honor for having achieved ICSA certification for five years in a row in the anti-virus (vaccine) field.

 

George Japak, Managing Director of ICSA Labs, commented that “Much effort is required to attain and maintain ICSA’s information security certification” and that “this year’s ICSA EIST award recognizes AhnLab’s ceaseless efforts to improve the performance of its products.” 

 

“This award demonstrates how the technological skill and performance of AhnLab’s V3 solution is continuing to receive recognition from global institutions,” said Luke H. W. R&D Director of AhnLab. “In the future, AhnLab will continue take the lead by fostering an ever safer security environment for customers through unflagging research development in security technology. 

 

To learn more about AhnLab V3 product, please visit ahnalb.com. 

 

About AhnLab, Inc.

Founded in 1995, AhnLab, Inc., the global leader in cybersecurity, delivers comprehensive protection for networks, transactions, and essential services. AhnLab delivers best-of-breed threat prevention that scales easily for highspeed networks, by combining cloud analysis with endpoint and server resources. AhnLab's multidimensional approach combines with exceptional service to create truly global protection against attacks that evade traditional security defenses.

 

That’s why more than 25,000 organizations rely on AhnLab’s award-winning products and services to make the internet safe and reliable for their business operations.
